answer: If there are seven runners, then their times could be: 6:00, 6:09.5, 6:19, 6:28.5, 6:38, 6:47.5, 6:59. The times are all in the range from six minutes up to 7 minutes and no two times are within nine seconds of each other.
instructions: Apply the pigeonhole principle to answer the following questions. If the pigeonhole principle can not be applied, give a specific counterexample.
question:
(b)

Seven members of the track team run the mile. Their mile times are all faster than 7 minutes but not faster than 6 minutes. Can you conclude that there are two runners whose times are less than nine seconds apart? What if there are eight runners? Times are measured to a precision of 0.01 second.
section: Exercise 4.20.1: Applying the pigeonhole principle -  heights and times.
